Marcelo,

Is there anything preventing someone from manually creating an ob=
ject
that has @Test annotations, and running it in NetBeans?

  David Saff
=

On Mon, Apr 20, 2009 at 10:15 AM, marcelo_javier_ruiz
<marcelo_javier_ruiz=
@...> wrote:
> Hi Karl,
>
> NetBeans has excellent support for JUn=
it. One of the very few features we are missing is generating a class from =
the test class (but this feature is coming and you can join the NetBeans co=
mmunity and vote for this issue and other issues related to JUnit).
> To fo=
llow Kent's approach what you need to do is first create the Dollar class i=
n the src folder as an empty class, and then create the test class in the t=
est folder.
> Now type the whole test. NetBeans will underline in red the l=
ines that have a problem. Go to that line and press Alt+Enter, and NetBeans=
 will present you the option to create the missing part in the source class=
. Once you can compile the test with no errors you can run it and make it f=
ail. Then you can put your effort in filling the source class with the logi=
c to make the test pass.
> I hope this is what you were looking for.
> All =
the best,
>
> Marcelo.
>
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Nat Pryce <nat.p=
ryce@...> wrote:
>>
>> I've not found the JUnit "support" in any IDE useful=
 for TDD. =A0They
>> all assume that you are testing a class that already e=
xists, and if it
>> does, they generate one test per method of that class, =
which produces
>> unhelpful test classes with unhelpfully named tests.
>>
>=
> --Nat
>>
>> 2009/4/19 Karl Krasnowsky <karlkras@...>:
>> >
>> >
>> > This=
 question is really targeted to those who have used Kent Beck's book,
>> > =
Test-Driven Development within the context of the NetBeans IDE, otherwise
>=
> > please disregard.
>> >
>> > Maybe someone here can provide a pointer to=
 already available information on
>> > this.
>> > I'm using Kent Beck's boo=
k, Test-Driven Development as a tutorial and was
>> > looking at how i migh=
t use NetBeans with its JUnit plugin to mimic his
>> > recommended processe=
s, but right out of the gate I'm having a fundamental
>> > issue.
>> > A st=
andard practice of KB's method is to code the test before any code is
>> > =
written, and then backfill the empty bits (class, methods, variables, etc.)=

>> > to make the test work.
>> > for example, here's the first JUnit test =
he shows in chapter 1 to begin
>> > building from:
>> > Code:
>> > public v=
oid testMultiplication() {
>> > Dollar five =3D new Dollar(5);
>> > five.ti=
mes(2);
>> > assertEquals(10, five.amount);
>> > }
>> >
>> > Problem I'm ha=
ving is, if I'm creating tests out of the context of the Java
>> > project,=
 tests in NB aren't created until you have a class with runtime
>> > method=
s to create tests from. So I have a chicken egg sort of situation. NB
>> > =
would do the obvious thing, i.e., have tests generated from code, so the
>>=
 > above doesn't make any sense as it implies that the code is generated fr=
om
>> > the test, which is a cool idea of the IDE could support it.
>> > I =
have experience using JUnit, so the framework itself isn't in question,
>> =
> but how to apply this methodology within the IDE format is.
>> > Do I hav=
e to simply short-circuit the default process that NB and the JUnit
>> > pl=
ugin manufacture?
>> >
>> > thanks in advance for any help on this,
>> > Ka=
rl
